speaker: C
text: Yeah, so I think what happened throughout the last year is that we've seen failure effectively of centralized protocols and everything from centralized bridging protocols to other exchanges and so on and so forth. They're all very, very centralized. And I think when it comes to cross chain, the stakes are high. In most of the use cases for cross chain, you are either moving value or information from one blockchain to another. The question whenever you move in this value, how is it protected and how is it secured on the backend? It's very easy to spin up a centralized server or a multisig to hold your funds, to move the information, to authorize it. But that has catastrophic effects, as we have seen. So these get compromised, you have bugs, sometimes you have operational issues, and so on and so forth. And so, at the end of the day, what we're trying to do with Axler and I think as an industry, we have to do is we have to learn how to build kind of decentralized cross chain or interoperable infrastructure that connects these decentralized platforms. You can't have a centralization in the middle for the same reason as you should not have a centralized actors in the web three space. It adds huge risks, it has huge robustness problems within it. So that's what we're trying to do with axillar, is build infrastructure that's secure, that's decentralized, and it has many layers of protections when it comes to cross chain everything from the right network to the right operations behind it. How do you do key rotations, how do you do validator membership changes, what types of code audits do you do, what types of rate limits do you have? And all those things. Our view is to take really a full stack approach at the problem and trying to tackle it from the bottom up.

If you go down a lot in the next year, let's say you go down all the way to 50. So if you're a salesman, you get paid to sell something, a car, but you don't get paid. The upside of Tesla over time growing as a company, you have to be a shareholder for that. text: Yeah, I'm going to be a bit of a gadfly here and say that I completely disagree. So I heard this thesis so many times in 2017, this was the original thesis of why tokens and icos and everything were going to take off. And it turned out that this thesis, for the most part, was completely wrong. So we first saw this tried out with icos, this idea, okay, Im going to sell you this token, and because you have this token, youre going to use my product. It turns out almost every single ICO that took place, people didnt use the product just because they bought the token. Then fast forward to another few years later and we have defi and liquidity mining. And the idea is that, okay, I'm going to give you tokens, and if I give you tokens, you'll use my product. And once again, we learned that, no, what people do is they farm the token and they sell it immediately and they never use the product at all. In fact, the people who are getting these tokens don't give a damn about the product. All they really want is to earn a yield. And of course, the other thing you find is that of the most beloved products in crypto didn't have tokens. And so you look at Opensea, no, token was obviously the dominant NFT trading platform. You looked at Uniswap, which became dominant before they even had a token. And the same thing was true for most of the applications in crypto that have really become super dominant. This idea anytime, and I say this as an investor because I spent a lot of time thinking about this and observing this. Anytime that you think your theory of why people are going to use this is because they're going to own my tokenization and that's why they're going to use my product. Almost always that is a bad theory. The theory of why people use products in web three or in anything is because they love the product, because it solves some problem they actually have. And if this were true, you would see crypto behaving very differently than it actually behaves. People see this sometimes with something like dogecoin, which is just a purely reflexive, memetic kind of community effectively. But most things in crypto that work don't look like that. They look like this is a great product and this token is integrated into a product that solves some other underlying problem. That's why it gets usage.

speaker: A
text: If you look at most traditional web two processes, almost always they have some kind of customer acquisition referral program, something like this that allows you, hey, if you use my product, you get 20% off if you use it at least ten times, something like this. These kinds of things are very common and they totally work. But the question is, what is the order of causation. People will use your product the first time, not because you offer them a carrot, but because it solves a problem that they have, and then they may increase your usage. They may shift usage away from other applications that they don't want to use as much. Like for you, if you were told, hey, take this enf, you know, make an ens name for yourself, maybe you'll get an airdrop. You'd be like, well, there are a thousand things I can maybe get an airdrop for, right? That's not what I'm going to be spending my time. But if you're like, hey, if I use this thing, that sounds interesting, I might also get a reward. And if I use it more, and if I refer a friend, I can get even more rewards. Okay, that's going to animate you. That's going to motivate you to really use this thing, right? If you look at Ethereum, the reason why people use Ethereum is not because they own. That's not why people use ethereum. People use Ethereum because ethereum is host to thousands of applications that people actually care about for underlying reasons. Most ether is owned by whales who just have it in custody, and it doesn't do anything, it just sits there. The reality is that I think in the very earliest stages, tokens can be effective in that kind of a flywheel. But anytime you think you've posited a positive feedback loop, positive feedback loops, if they actually do work, generally speaking, they have very decreasing marginal utility. Otherwise, a token that does that would just end up having a billion dollar market cap the next day because the feedback loop would continue forever. Almost no feedback loops work like that. Feedback loops almost always decay as they get bigger, which means that, okay, there's some initial juice you get from having a token and incentivizing something, but then it hits a wall and you got to just build the best product. And that's what, when I talk to entrepreneurs, that's mostly what I tell them, is that tokenomics is not going to save you. You got to actually build a better mousetrap.
